document.docAuthor: Seeman, Owen D., Lindquist, Evert E. & Husband, Robert W.
document.docTitle: Podotarsonemus australiensis Seeman & Lindquist & Husband 2018, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: A new tribe of tarsonemid mites (Trombidiformes: Heterostigmatina) parasitic on tetrigid grasshoppers (Orthoptera)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A new tribe of tarsonemid mites (Trombidiformes: Heterostigmatina) parasitic on tetrigid grasshoppers (Orthoptera)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type material. Holotype. Adult female. AUSTRALIA , Spear Creek, Mt Molloy, Far North Queensland, 22 Jun 1975 , G.B. Monteith, ex
Loxilobus
sp. ( Tetrigidae ) ( Fig. 29A ). In QM.

Paratypes . 7 females , 1 male , 2 larvae , same data as holotype
. All in QM except 1 female in each of CNCI and UMMZ.

Non-type material. 1 female, PAPUA NEW GUINEA , Upper Gusap River, near Butemu, Madang Dist., Oct 1965 , R. Pullen, 3500 â€² alt., ex
Scelimena erimeta (GÃ¼nther)
( Tetrigidae ). In QM.

Diagnosis. Female and male: Palps with 1 seta; chelicerae with 2 teeth; prodorsal plate entirely punctate; femur I with rudimentary setae lÊ¹ and d ; femur II with tiny seta d , lacking lÊ¹ and vâ€³ ; genua IIâ€“III with 3 setae; tarsi IIâ€“III with 5 setae, seta uÊ¹Ê¹ present; trochanter IV with seta. Female: Setae sc1 absent; vestigial setae
v2
expressed as anterolateral invaginations; coxisternal plates IIIâ€“IV separated medially by longitudinal striae; setae h attenuate, 40â€“51 long; femorogenu IV with 2 setae; tracheal atria separate, post-atrial sac lightly sclerotized, not punctate. Male: Genital capsule without copulatory flanges; setae h2 developed, length 4â€“6; femorogenu IV with 1 seta; tibia IV with solenidion and attenuate seta; tarsus IV terminal, bearing 3 setae and claw. Male and larva: Leg I with tibia and tarsus I separate. Larva: Setae h1-2 , ps2 attenuate, setae ps1 short; leg I with 2 small claws.
Description. ADULT FEMALE ( Figures 1â€“2 , 5A, B, n = 8 measured)

Gnathosoma .
Length 63â€“69, width 58â€“80. Palps 10â€“12, with 1 seta (2 long). Cheliceral stylets 25â€“27, with 2 teeth. Pharynx length 30â€“33, width 17. Dorsal setae ch 30â€“35, ventral setae su 6â€“14, palpcoxal setae e 7â€“13.

Idiosoma
. Length 255â€“310, width 165â€“197. Tracheal atria separate, post-atrial sac lightly sclerotized, not punctate, terminal tracheae not visible. Prodorsal plate with punctate sculpturing, 102â€“104 long, 130â€“140 wide; with 2 pairs of setae:
v1 22
â€“25, thickened, tapering, with barbs, sc2 66â€“75 and vestigial
v2
expressed as anterolateral invaginations. Distance between setae
v1-v1 55
â€“60,
v2-v2 62
â€“70, sc2-sc2 72â€“
80, v1
-sc2 34. Plates C, D, EF and H with punctate sculpturing, plate H heavily so. Setae c1, d, e, f tapering, with small barbs,
c 1
19â€“27, c2 54â€“64, d 21â€“27, e 20â€“24, f 24â€“28. Distance between setae c1-c1 97â€“110, c2-c2 148â€“165,
c1-c 2
22â€“25, d-d 78â€“87, e-e 83â€“87, f-f 35â€“44. Setae h tapering, 50â€“51. Distance between setae h-h 25â€“31. Cupules ia present, tiny, im absent, ih present. Setae ps attenuate> 250, distance between setae ps-ps 12â€“14. Coxisternal setae short to attenuate, 1a 11â€“12, 2a > 140, 3a > 230, 3b > 150. Distance between setae 1a-1a 17â€“20, 2a-2a 42â€“46, 3a-3a 10â€“ 12, 3b-3b 14â€“24; alveolar vestiges of setae 1b, 2b barely discernible. Coxisternal plates IIIâ€“IV separated by longitudinal striae; coxisternal plates III convex anteriorly, overlapping posterior margin of coxisterna II.
Legs. Leg lengths: I 56 â€“62, II 62 â€“66, III 45 â€“49. Leg IV Fe-Ge length 29â€“32, Ti-Ta length 14â€“16. Leg III, femur and genu fused.

Femur I, lÊ¹ , d rudimentary, lÊ¹Ê¹ 1â€“2, vÊ¹Ê¹ 10â€“14; genu I lÊ¹ 2â€“3, lÊ¹Ê¹ 2â€“3, vÊ¹ 2â€“4, vÊ¹Ê¹ 3â€“4; tibia and tarsus I fused, tibial setae d 30â€“35, lÊ¹ 4â€“6, lÊ¹Ê¹ 4â€“5, vÊ¹ 8â€“10, vÊ¹Ê¹ 4â€“7, solenidion Ï† 3; tarsal setae tcÊ¹ 14â€“15, tcÊ¹Ê¹ 12â€“14, pvÊ¹ 7â€“10, pvÊ¹Ê¹ 6â€“7, s spine-like, 8â€“9, solenidion Ï‰ 7.

Femur II d 1â€“2; genu II lÊ¹ 3â€“4, lÊ¹Ê¹ 4â€“5, vÊ¹ 3â€“5; tibia II d 20â€“22, lÊ¹ 7â€“8, vÊ¹ 15â€“16, vÊ¹Ê¹ 15â€“18; tarsus II pvÊ¹ 12â€“16, tcÊ¹ 12â€“15, tcÊ¹Ê¹ 17â€“21, uÊ¹ spine-like, 8â€“10, uÊ¹Ê¹ 3â€“5, solenidion Ï‰ 6â€“7.
Genu III lÊ¹ 3â€“4, lÊ¹Ê¹ 5, vÊ¹ 3â€“4; Tibia III d 14â€“15, lÊ¹ 17, vÊ¹ 7â€“8, vÊ¹Ê¹ 14â€“16; tarsus III pvÊ¹ 12â€“16, tcÊ¹ 16â€“18, tcÊ¹Ê¹ 18, uÊ¹ spine-like, 8, uÊ¹Ê¹ 2â€“3.

Trochanter IV with ventral seta vÊ¹ 10â€“12; femorogenu IV with proximal femoral seta vÊ¹ 5â€“6, distal genual seta vÊ¹ 18â€“23; tibiotarsus with attenuate ventral tibial seta vÊ¹ > 100 and terminal tarsal seta tcâ€³ > 350.
ADULT MALE ( Figs 3â€“4 , 5C, n = 1)

Gnathosoma .
Length 48, width 54. Palps 8. Cheliceral stylets 19, with 2 teeth. Pharynx length 28, width 14. Dorsal setae 20, ventral setae 5, palpcoxal setae 5.

Idiosoma
. Length 200, width 160. Prodorsal plate punctate, 82 long, 110 wide; with 3 pairs of setae (
v1 24
, sc1 12, sc2 55) and vestigial
v2
expressed as anterolateral invaginations. Distance between setae
v1-v1 37
,
v2â€“v2 48
, sc1-sc1 70, sc2-sc2
69, v1
-sc2 50. Plate CD punctate. Setae c1 tapering, with small barbs, 24, c2 fine, 44, d with small barbs, 27 (asymmetrical, extra d expressed on right hand side); setae
c 1
in nearly transverse alignment with c2 . Plate EF punctate, e 17, f 24, with small barbs. Distance between setae c1-c1 88, c2-c2 144, c1-c2 27, d-d 63, e- e 34, f-f 25. Cupules ia , im , ih indiscernible or absent. Genital capsule 47 long, 38 wide, bearing setae h1 6 long and alveolar remnants of h2 ; ventral flanges absent. Coxisternal setae short to attenuate 1a 14, 2a > 60, 3a> 80, 3b > 10 (broken). Distance between setae 1a-1a 20, 2a-2a 34, 3a-3a 8, 3b-3b 38; alveolar vestiges of setae 1b, 2b indiscernible or absent; setae 1a just posterior to ap1, setae 2a far posterior to ap2. Apodemes: ap2 almost reaching medially obsolete ap sj; ap5 well developed, fused, extending 45â€“50 anteriorly from base.
Legs. Leg lengths: I 55 , II 58 , III 54 , IV 45 â€“51. Leg III, femur and genu separate.

Femur I, lÊ¹ , d rudimentary, lÊ¹Ê¹ 2, vÊ¹Ê¹ 10; genu I lÊ¹ 3, lÊ¹Ê¹ 3, vÊ¹ 3, vÊ¹Ê¹ 4; tibia and tarsus I separate, tibial setae d 28, lÊ¹ 6, lÊ¹Ê¹ 5, vÊ¹ 5, vÊ¹Ê¹ 11, solenidion Ï† 3; tarsal setae ftÊ¹ 8, ftÊ¹Ê¹ 8, tcÊ¹ 14, tcÊ¹Ê¹ 14, pvÊ¹ 10, pvÊ¹Ê¹ 8, s spine-like, 8, solenidion Ï‰ 7. Femur II d 2; genu II lÊ¹ 4, lÊ¹Ê¹ 6, vÊ¹ 3; tibia II d 14, lÊ¹ 15, vÊ¹ 7, vÊ¹Ê¹ 20; tarsus II pvÊ¹ 10, tcÊ¹ 15, tcÊ¹Ê¹ 20, uÊ¹ spine-like, 9, uÊ¹Ê¹ 6, solenidion Ï‰ 10.

Trochanter IV with ventral seta 7 long; femorogenu IV with proximal seta 2; tibia IV with solenidion Ï† 17 and ventral seta attenuate,> 120; tarsus IV terminal, with uÊ¹ 4, tcÊ¹Ê¹ 2, pvÊ¹Ê¹ rudimentary, and claw 3.
LARVA ( Fig. 6 , n = 2)

Gnathosoma .
Length 58â€“50, width 43â€“56. Palps 10â€“11. Cheliceral stylets 24â€“25, with 2 teeth. Pharynx length 26â€“30, width 14â€“15. Dorsal setae 7â€“10, ventral setae 4â€“5.

Idiosoma
. Length 255â€“350, width 142â€“225. Prodorsal plate smooth, 70â€“76 long, 111â€“125 wide; with 3 pairs of tapering, weakly barbed setae (
v1 10
, sc1 8â€“9,
sc 2
20â€“21) and vestigial
v2 .
Distance between setae
v1-v1 35
,
v2-v2 56
, sc1-sc1 77â€“79, sc2-sc2 68â€“
70, v1
-sc2 24. Plates C, D, EF punctate. Setae tapering, barbed,
c 1
15â€“17,
c 2
13â€“15, d 16â€“18, e 16, f 20â€“21. Distance between setae c1-c1 76, c2-c2 127,
c1-c 2
30â€“33, d-d 50â€“52, e-e 50â€“53, f-f 23â€“26. Plate H punctate, setae h1 attenuate,> 160, h2 ventral, attenuate, > 200. Distance between setae h1 24. Cupules ia , im present, ih indiscernible or absent. Setae ps1 fine, 10, ps2 attenuate 35â€“55. Coxisternal setae 1a 5â€“10, 2a 35â€“40, 3a attenuate,> 160, 3b 39. Distance between setae 1a-1a 17â€“21, 2a-2a 45, 3a-3a 32, 3b-3b 39; alveolar vestiges of setae 1b, 2b present.

Legs. Femur I d , lÊ¹ , lÊ¹Ê¹ rudimentary, vÊ¹Ê¹ 6â€“8; genu I lÊ¹ rudimentary, lÊ¹Ê¹ 1, vÊ¹ rudimentary, vÊ¹Ê¹ 1; tibia and tarsus I separate, tibial setae d 10â€“12, lÊ¹ 3â€“5, lÊ¹Ê¹ 3, vÊ¹ 3â€“4, vÊ¹Ê¹ 7â€“10, solenidion Ï† 3, tarsal setae tcÊ¹ 11â€“13, tcÊ¹Ê¹ 10â€“12, pvÊ¹ 5, pvÊ¹Ê¹ 3â€“5, s spine-like, 5, solenidion Ï‰ 5â€“6.
Femur II d rudimentary; tibia II d 7â€“9, lÊ¹ 4â€“5, vÊ¹ 12, vÊ¹Ê¹ 8â€“11; tarsus II tcÊ¹ 10, tcÊ¹Ê¹ 11, pÊ¹ 1, uÊ¹ spine-like, 6, uÊ¹Ê¹ 1â€“ 2, solenidion Ï‰ 4â€“5.
Tibia III d 7â€“8, lÊ¹ 4â€“5, vÊ¹ 9â€“12, vÊ¹Ê¹ 10â€“12; tarsus III pvÊ¹ 11, tcÊ¹ 10â€“14, tcÊ¹Ê¹ 6, pÊ¹ 1â€“2, uÊ¹ spine-like, 6â€“7, uÊ¹Ê¹ 1. Leg I with 2 small claws.

Etymology. The species name
australiensis
refers to the name of the country where the type specimens were collected.

Remarks.
Podotarsonemus
can be divided into two species groups. The first group (
australiensis
species group, including
P. australiensis
,
P. indicus
and
P. zuluensis
) all retains seta vÊ¹ on trochanter IV, has females with longitudinal striae between coxisterna IIIâ€“IV and setae h not attenuated, and males that retain at least a rudimentary tarsus on leg IV. In contrast, females of the second group (
boliviensis
species group, including
P. boliviensis , P. ecuadorensis , P. nipponicus , P. queenslandensis
) have lost seta vÊ¹ on trochanter IV, have no longitudinal striae between coxisterna IIIâ€“IV, have attenuate setae h , and males lack tarsus IV.

The
australiensis
species group is possibly artificial because it is based on putative plesiomorphies. Of all its members,
P. australiensis
is perhaps the most plesiotypic species. In addition to the abovementioned features of the
australiensis
species group,
P. australiensis
is the only species that retains setae on genua IIâ€“III and has males with a divided tibia and tarsus I, tarsal structures on leg IV and a well-developed h seta. Despite these plesiomorphic attributes,
P. australiensis
also has the apomorphic loss of setae sc1 on the adult female, which is shared with
P. queenslandensis
and
P. zuluensis .
This feature is probably a homoplasious loss, as both these species belong in separate species groups. Another apomorphic loss is seta lÊ¹ on femur II (absent in all species except
P. boliviensis
and
P. ecuadorensis
) and the loss of seta vâ€³ on femur II, which is autapomorphic in the Acarapinae .

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 6.
Podotarsonemus australiensis
sp. nov.
larva, dorsum.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Exceptionally for the Tarsonemidae , the setae on genua IIâ€“III are absent in the larva but present in the adult. The delay in expression of these setae is an example of in-process evolutionary ontogenetic suppression, and while unusual in the Tarsonemidae , such ontogenetic delays are often reported for leg setae in other major taxa (e.g., see
Beard et al. (2014)
on the Tenuipalpidae ). Curiously, considerable leg setal reductions also occur in the larvae of species of
Acarapis
, which retain just one tibial and two tarsal setae. However, adults of all three species retain a near-fully developed leg chaetome for the Acarapinae ; hence the ontogenetic suppression of these setae is not connected with evolutionary trends towards simplification of leg setae. Instead, larvae of
Acarapis
show reductions in their gross leg morphology, suggesting their reductive trend is closely related to the apparent immobility of their larval stage.

The material examined includes one non-type female from Papua New Guinea that we have included under
P. australiensis
. The specimen matches the Australian specimens reasonably well but is in poor condition, lacking setae sc2, c1, c2, d and e . However, many of its leg setae are longer, such as femur I d (2 versus rudimentary), and tibia I d (45 versus 30â€“35) and vâ€³ (24 versus 4â€“7). Its host genus is also different: although both are Scelimeninae ,
Scelimena
belongs to the Scelimenini while
Loxilobus
belongs to the Criotettigini . The differences in leg setal lengths and different host tribes suggest that this mite may be a different species, but more collections are required to test this hypothesis.
